interaction_modifiers.name: Iron-Deficiency Anemia Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: Low hemoglobin combined with low ferritin strongly suggests iron-deficiency anemia. The combination is more significant than either marker alone.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Confirms iron-deficiency as the cause of anemia rather than other etiologies. Requires iron supplementation and dietary intervention.

activity: Light to moderate exercise only until Hb improves above 10 g/dL
Avoid high-intensity exercise which increases iron demand
nutrition: Iron-rich foods: spinach, lentils, tofu, dark chocolate
Pair iron foods with Vitamin C (lemon, orange) to boost absorption
Avoid tea/coffee within 1 hour of iron-rich meals
lifestyle: Prioritize 8+ hours of sleep for recovery
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Punarnava (Boerhavia diffusa) for blood building
Ayurvedic: Loha Bhasma (iron ash) under practitioner guidance
Yoga: Gentle pranayama (Anulom Vilom) for oxygenation

interaction_modifiers.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency Anemia Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: Low hemoglobin with low Vitamin B12 suggests megaloblastic anemia. Different treatment pathway than iron-deficiency anemia.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Megaloblastic anemia pattern. B12 deficiency affects both blood cell production and neurological function.

activity: Moderate walking 20-30 mins daily
Balance exercises to counteract B12-related neuropathy risk
nutrition: B12-rich foods: fortified cereals, dairy, eggs
For vegans: fortified nutritional yeast, plant milks
Fermented foods for gut B12 absorption
supplementation: Vitamin B12 (consult provider; sublingual or injection may be needed)
lifestyle: Stress management as stress depletes B12
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Ashwagandha for nerve health support
Ayurvedic: Brahmi (Bacopa monnieri) for cognitive support
Yoga: Sarvangasana (shoulder stand) for thyroid and circulation

interaction_modifiers.name: Metabolic Syndrome Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: High fasting glucose + high triglycerides + low HDL indicates metabolic syndrome, a cluster of conditions that significantly increase cardiovascular risk.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Metabolic syndrome diagnosis requires 3 of 5 criteria. This biomarker combination alone confirms 3 criteria and warrants immediate intervention.

activity: Aerobic exercise 150 min/week minimum (brisk walking, swimming, cycling)
Resistance training 2-3 times/week for insulin sensitivity
Post-meal walking 10-15 mins to blunt glucose spikes
nutrition: Limit refined carbs and added sugars
Omega-3 rich foods (salmon, walnuts, chia seeds)
Portion control — caloric deficit if overweight
supplementation: Omega-3 fatty acids (consult provider for dosage)
lifestyle: Weight loss target: 5-7% of body weight
Stress reduction: cortisol drives insulin resistance
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Gymnema Sylvestre (Gurmar) — reduces sugar cravings
Ayurvedic: Fenugreek (Methi) seeds soaked overnight
Ayurvedic: Triphala for digestive metabolism
Yoga: Surya Namaskar (Sun Salutation) for full-body metabolism
Yoga: Kapalbhati Pranayama for abdominal organs

interaction_modifiers.name: Prediabetes Confirmation Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: Both fasting glucose (100-125) and HbA1c (5.7-6.4%) being elevated confirms prediabetes per ADA criteria.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Dual-marker confirmation of prediabetes. Higher conversion risk to Type 2 Diabetes than single-marker elevation.

activity: Structured exercise program: 150 min moderate-intensity/week
Include both cardio and strength training
Walking after every major meal (10-15 mins)
nutrition: Limit fruit juices and refined carbs
lifestyle: Weight management plan with 5-7% body weight loss goal
Stress management: elevated cortisol worsens insulin resistance
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Bitter gourd (Karela) juice on empty stomach
Ayurvedic: Jamun (Indian Blackberry) seed powder
Ayurvedic: Vijaysar (Pterocarpus marsupium) bark water
Yoga: Mandukasana (Frog pose) for pancreatic stimulation
Yoga: Ardha Matsyendrasana (spinal twist) for abdominal organs

interaction_modifiers.name: Cardiovascular Risk Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: High LDL + low HDL + elevated hs-CRP indicates combined dyslipidemia with active inflammation — a high-risk pattern for cardiovascular events.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Triple threat: atherogenic lipid profile plus vascular inflammation. Aggressive intervention warranted.

activity: Cardiovascular exercise 30-60 mins, 5 days/week
Brisk walking, swimming, or cycling preferred
Avoid isometric/heavy lifting until lipids improve
nutrition: Soluble fiber: oats, barley, beans, apples
Omega-3 fatty acids: salmon, sardines, mackerel
Avoid trans fats and limit saturated fats
supplementation: Omega-3 fish oil (consult provider for dosage)
CoQ10 (consult provider — especially if on statins)
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Arjuna (Terminalia arjuna) bark — cardioprotective
Ayurvedic: Guggul (Commiphora mukul) for lipid management
Ayurvedic: Garlic (Lasuna) for cholesterol
Yoga: Shavasana (Corpse pose) for deep relaxation
Yoga: Bhramari Pranayama for blood pressure regulation

interaction_modifiers.name: Thyroid-Metabolic Disruption
interaction_modifiers.description: High TSH (hypothyroid) combined with high cholesterol suggests thyroid-driven dyslipidemia. Treating the thyroid may normalize lipids.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Hypothyroidism causes secondary hyperlipidemia. Lipids may normalize with thyroid treatment alone, avoiding unnecessary statin therapy.

activity: Moderate exercise despite fatigue — helps thyroid function
Morning exercise preferred for metabolism boost
Avoid over-exercising which can worsen thyroid function
supplementation: Vitamin D (often co-deficient with thyroid issues, consult provider)
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Kanchanar Guggul for thyroid support
Ayurvedic: Ashwagandha for thyroid hormone balance
Ayurvedic: Jalkumbhi (water hyacinth) for iodine
Yoga: Sarvangasana (Shoulder stand) for thyroid stimulation
Yoga: Matsyasana (Fish pose) — thyroid and parathyroid

interaction_modifiers.name: Inflammation-Liver Stress Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: High hs-CRP + high SGPT/ALT indicates systemic inflammation with liver involvement. Could suggest NAFLD or hepatitis.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Liver is both a source and target of inflammation. This pattern requires liver imaging and viral hepatitis panel.

activity: Moderate-intensity exercise (helps reduce liver fat)
Walking 30 mins daily minimum
Avoid strenuous exercise until liver enzymes normalize
nutrition: Avoid processed foods, excess sugar, and trans fats
supplementation: Milk thistle / Silymarin (consult provider for dosage)
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Kutki (Picrorhiza kurroa) for liver protection
Ayurvedic: Bhumi Amla (Phyllanthus niruri) for liver health
Ayurvedic: Kalmegh (Andrographis) for liver inflammation
Yoga: Ardha Matsyendrasana (seated twist) for liver massage
Yoga: Dhanurasana (Bow pose) for liver stimulation

interaction_modifiers.name: Multiple Nutritional Deficiency Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: Low Vitamin D + Low Ferritin + Low B12 suggests global malabsorption or chronic dietary insufficiency.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Triple deficiency pattern. Consider malabsorption syndromes (Celiac, Crohn's), chronic gastritis, or chronic dietary insufficiency. Screening for GI conditions recommended.

activity: Light exercise only — fatigue from multi-deficiency is real
Gentle yoga or tai chi
Outdoor walking for Vitamin D synthesis (15-30 mins)
nutrition: For non-veg: liver, shellfish, salmon, eggs
For veg: fortified plant milks, nutritional yeast, sprouted grains
Consider anti-inflammatory diet to support gut absorption
supplementation: Multivitamin with iron, B12, and D3 (consult provider)
Consider injectable B12 if oral absorption is poor
Vitamin D3 (consult provider for dosage based on levels)
Iron bisglycinate (gentler on stomach, consult provider)
lifestyle: Daily sunlight exposure 15-30 minutes (for Vitamin D)
Gut health focus: probiotics, fermented foods
Screen for celiac disease and other malabsorption
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Chyawanprash for overall nutritional support
Ayurvedic: Triphala for gut absorption improvement
Ayurvedic: Shatavari for nutrient assimilation
Yoga: Pavanamuktasana (Wind-relieving) for digestive health
Meditation: Yoga Nidra for deep restorative rest

interaction_modifiers.name: Mixed Dyslipidemia Pattern
interaction_modifiers.description: High LDL + High Triglycerides together indicate mixed dyslipidemia requiring both dietary and lifestyle intervention.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Mixed dyslipidemia accelerates atherosclerosis. Lifestyle modification is first-line therapy.

activity: Aerobic exercise 30 mins, 5 days/week
Swimming or cycling preferred
Consistent daily movement — avoid sedentary periods > 1 hour
nutrition: Reduce saturated fat to < 7% of calories
supplementation: Red yeast rice (consult provider — natural statin)
Psyllium husk for soluble fiber (consult provider)
lifestyle: Weight management — even 5% loss improves lipids
Regular lipid panel monitoring every 3 months
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Guggul (Commiphora mukul) for cholesterol reduction
Ayurvedic: Arjuna bark tea for heart health
Yoga: Paschimottanasana (seated forward bend) for digestion
Yoga: Trikonasana (Triangle pose) for circulation

interaction_modifiers.name: Vitamin D Deficiency with Inflammation
interaction_modifiers.description: Low Vitamin D + High hs-CRP. Vitamin D is a key immunomodulator; its deficiency amplifies inflammatory pathways.
interaction_modifiers.clinical_significance: Vitamin D deficiency potentiates chronic inflammation. Correcting D levels often reduces CRP independently.

activity: Outdoor exercise for sun exposure + physical activity
Morning walks (before 10 AM) for optimal UV exposure
Moderate intensity to avoid exercise-induced inflammation
nutrition: Vitamin D rich foods: fatty fish, fortified milk, egg yolks
Anti-inflammatory foods: berries, leafy greens, turmeric
Avoid pro-inflammatory foods: processed meats, sugar
supplementation: Vitamin D3 (consult provider for dosage based on blood levels)
Curcumin with black pepper for anti-inflammatory effect (consult provider)
lifestyle: 15-30 mins daily sun exposure on arms and face
Stress reduction: cortisol blocks vitamin D receptors
alternate_healing: Ayurvedic: Guduchi (Tinospora cordifolia) — immunomodulator
Ayurvedic: Amalaki (Indian Gooseberry) for inflammation
Yoga: Surya Namaskar (Sun Salutation) in morning sunlight
Pranayama: Bhastrika for immune system stimulation

trigger_patterns.pattern: Low Hb + Normal Ferritin + Normal B12
trigger_patterns.diagnosis: Anemia of Chronic Disease — further workup needed
Anemia (type to be determined by MCV)
Confirmed Prediabetes or Diabetes (per ADA criteria)
Acute glucose elevation — repeat fasting test recommended

trigger_patterns.pattern: High Glucose + High TG + Low HDL

trigger_patterns.diagnosis: Atherogenic dyslipidemia — 10yr CVD risk evaluation needed

trigger_patterns.pattern: High TC + High LDL + Normal HDL
High LDL + Low HDL + High CRP
trigger_patterns.diagnosis: High cardiovascular risk — aggressive intervention needed

trigger_patterns.pattern: Low Ferritin + Low B12 + Low D

trigger_patterns.diagnosis: Inflammation amplified by vitamin D deficiency
Non-specific inflammation — infection, autoimmune, or CVD risk

trigger_patterns.pattern: High ALT + High TG + High Glucose

trigger_patterns.diagnosis: Isolated liver enzyme elevation — monitor and lifestyle modification

priority_rules.description: Rules for AI to determine priority ordering of findings and recommendations

priority_levels.name: Critical / Immediate
priority_levels.criteria: Panic/critical values, confirmed multi-marker disease patterns, metabolic syndrome

priority_levels.name: High Priority
priority_levels.criteria: Two-marker interaction patterns, significant deviations (>30%), confirmed deficiency patterns
priority_levels.action_timeframe: Address within 1-2 weeks; schedule provider visit

priority_levels.name: Moderate
priority_levels.criteria: Single marker abnormalities, mild deviations, isolated findings
priority_levels.action_timeframe: Address within 1-3 months through lifestyle changes

priority_levels.name: Maintenance / Prevention
priority_levels.criteria: Borderline values, preventive optimization, values at edges of normal

ordering_rules: Multi-marker interaction findings take priority over single-marker findings
Within same priority level, order by deviation percentage (highest first)
Cluster-confirmed diagnoses rank higher than isolated marker abnormalities
Treatable conditions rank higher than conditions requiring only monitoring
